title: Identity

articles.content:
To exist is to be something, as distinguished from the nothing of
non-existence, it is to be an entity of a specific nature made of specific
attributes. Centuries ago, the man who was—no matter what his errors—the
greatest of your philosophers, has stated the formula defining the concept of
existence and the rule of all knowledge: A is A. A thing is itself. You have
never grasped the meaning of his statement. I am here to complete it: Existence
is Identity, Consciousness is Identification.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 125

articles.content:
A thing is—what it is; its characteristics constitute its identity. An
existent apart from its characteristics, would be an existent apart from its
identity, which means: a nothing, a non-existent.
articles.attribution:
Leonard Peikoff, “The Analytic-Synthetic Dichotomy,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 142

articles.content:
No matter how eagerly you claim that the goal of your mystic wishing is a
higher mode of life, the rebellion against identity is the wish for
non-existence. The desire not to be anything is the desire not to be.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 150

articles.content:
A characteristic is an aspect of an existent. It is not a disembodied, Platonic
universal. Just as a concept cannot mean existents apart from their identity,
so it cannot mean identities apart from that which exists. Existence is
Identity.
articles.attribution:
Leonard Peikoff, “The Analytic-Synthetic Dichotomy,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 106

articles.content: The concept “identity” does not indicate the particular natures of the existents it subsumes; it merely underscores the primary fact that they are what they are.
The law of identity does not permit you to have your cake and eat it, too. The law of causality does not permit you to eat your cake before you have it. . . .
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 152

articles.content: The (implicit) concept “existent” undergoes three stages of development in man’s mind. The first stage is a child’s awareness of objects, of things—which represents the (implicit) concept “entity.” The second and closely allied stage is the awareness of specific, particular things which he can recognize and distinguish from the rest of his perceptual field—which represents the (implicit) concept “identity.”
articles.attribution:
“Cognition and Measurement,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 6

articles.content: They proclaim that there is no law of identity, that nothing exists but change, and blank out the fact that change presupposes the concepts of what changes, from what and to what, that without the law of identity no such concept as “change” is possible.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 154

acknowledgement:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 125
